ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Mostly a live virtual lecture, with some discussion/seminar components as well.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I not only learned about the Tale of Genji itself, but I was exposed to a whole new world and culture of Japan from 1000 years ago. It was fascinating to learn how the social customs and currents of the time impacted the writing of the Tale, and I really enjoyed discussing the lasting effects/impacts the text had on Japanese society and the world more broadly. We also had a lot of practice with textual analysis, both for the prose and poetry portions of the Talein and of itself I didn't really take this class to learn how to analyze a text, but some of the concepts we discussed (such as recursion, textual memory, and mono no aware) were new and interesting to learn about.
Reading of the Tale of Genji and writing a Humanity paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I thought this course was very well-paced and had a good balance overall, which helped a lot during remote learning. Reading the text took up the majority of the semester (as it should for a 1300 page book!) and even though the readings sometimes got a little lengthy, they were never overwhelming. I also thought that Professor Kamens is an incredible asset to this class, as he is incredibly knowledgeable about the Tale and kept exploring new topics in lectures right to the very end of the course.

One weakness is that I would have loved to see a little more involvement from the classwe had a small enough group that seminar discussions were feasible, but they often ended up being squished into the final 10 or 15 minutes of lecture. I wonder if there is some way to keep providing the great content that is in the lectures themselves while still allowing for some more engagement during class time.

They gave us clear and detailed feedback to our every assignment, by which I was able to greatly improve my writing. In that sense, the 1 on 1 office hours were really helpful. Also, when I had a family emergency and had to skip a few classes, they were very flexible about it, and I cannot thank them enough.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this course ran pretty well considering the challenges of remote learning, and didn't feel like I lost too much content because of the circumstances. As with any course I think the biggest challenge is keeping people engaged (I sometimes found my mind wandering during the lectures) and so I think this would be the biggest area to focus on in the future.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! The Tale of Genji was something entirely out of my area of expertise, and I came in with zero knowledge of what I was going to be learning about. This course did a really great job of bringing everyone into the world of Genji regardless of prior knowledge, and I learned so many interesting things even though the class didn't have too heavy a workload. I also loved that we were able to spend the entire semester on one textI was able to read the Tale cover to cover (which was my main goal coming in) and de-prioritize some of the secondary sources we also read without losing much content from the class. For anybody looking to explore something new and really immerse yourself in one topic/period in history for a semester, this is the course for you!
If you are interested in literature or want to improve your Humanity writing, absolutely
